repnme.cdata!:
Kenya - Tana River Primate National Reserve
            Conservation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are as follows: Project
            outcome is unsatisfactory; sustainability is unlikely;
            institutional development impact is modest; overall Bank
            performance is unsatisfactory; and overall Borrower
            performance is unsatisfactory. Two major lessons may be
            drawn from the experience of this project: 1) Uncertainty
            must be removed from core components before implementation
            begins. The fact that in this case the program for
            relocating those willing to move from the reserve was not
            agreed before the project became effective handicapped the
            implementation of the whole community development component.
            Unless local communities believe that their interests are
            central to project design, they are unlikely to actively
            support implementation. 2) When a relatively small,
            stand-alone objective, such as conserving the unique
            biodiversity of the Tana River Primate National Reserve, is
            considered as the basis for a project, the design must look
            beyond the immediate area linked to project operations, and
            must take into account those conditions in the wider region
            that can have a crucial impact on its success or failure.

6538485.trustfund:
TF023410-SIDA CTF FOR ENVIRONMENT,TF028500-GEF1-KENYA TANA RIVER PRIMATE
            NATIONAL RESERVE CONVERSATION,TF028601-GET-PPA FOR KENYA TANA RIVER PROJECT,TF031250-AFRICA - SOCIAL ANTHROPOLOGY,TF032315-AFRICA REGION (KENYA;UGANDA) -

repnme.cdata!:
Kenya - Tana River Primate National Reserve
            Conservation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated
            unsatisfactory. Sustainability of the modest project
            achievement, of relative stability of the primate
            populations, and (perhaps) a reduction in the rate of
            habitat destruction and degradation within the project zone,
            is unlikely, following an abrupt closure of the project in
            the absence of further intervention. Both the World
            Bank's and Borrower's performances received an
            unsatisfactory rating. Lessons learned were several: 1)
            Unless communities believe that their interests are at the
            heart of project design, they are unlikely to actively
            support project implementation. Making the improvement of
            local livelihoods a secondary objective, merely to reduce
            pressure on biodiversity, may be counterproductive. 2) A
            four-year time horizon is insufficient to achieve
            significant community participation, change livelihood
            strategies, and complete a voluntary relocation exercise, in
            a situation where community support for the project at the
            outset is at best shaky and divided, especially when the
            executing agency has little prior experience in managing
            such activities. 3) The eligibility of expenditures, to
            promote sustainable economic development as a strategy for
            achieving sustainable global beenfits for biodiversity
            conservation, must be agreed upon prior to project approval,
            and realistic cost estimates for such expenditures must be
            included in the project document. 4) This project
            demonstrated that even in situations where there is a lack
            of trust, it is possible to have dialoguw with community
            members, and better participation by communities in reserve
            managmeent can be achieved. 5) Complex and conflicting
            management and reporting lines for project staff operating
            in the context of a larger institution, can cause delays in
            decision-making and project implementation. 6)
            Administrative capacity of the implementing agency and major
            collaborating institutions, in carrying out procurement,
            financial management and reporting, must be considered very
            carefully when establishing project disbursement schedules.
            7) The government and other stakeholders considered the
            resettlement package expensive, and raised concerns about
            precendents being set, which would be impossible to follow
            in future non-Bank-funded activities. A less comprehensive
            compensation package might not have raised the same concern
            about the project having shifted all its emphasis and
            resources onto resettlement activities. 8)When significant
            activities in the critical path, such as research and
            monitoring, are to be carried out by a cooperating
            institution, rather than directly by the executing agency,
            it is essential to ensure that the operational linkages for
            this collaboration are clear and workable. A functional
            Project Steering Committee will then be all the more
            important to ensure performance of all partners. 9) Conflict
            can arise when the Bank as implementing agency must follow
            its internal operational policies and procedures when it
            comes to issues like resettlement, and GEF, as the source of
            funding, clooses not to finance the implementation
            activities necessary for compliance with Bank policies.

repnme.cdata!: Kenya - Tana River Primate National Reserve Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Tana River Primate National Reserve
            Project support the conservation of a unique and diverse
            biological community in Kenya. The project will strengthen
            the Kenya Wildlife Service's (KWS') capacity to
            protect and manage the reserve in a traditional sense, but
            will also promote greater involvement of local communities
            in conservation and management of the area. The project will
            be implemented over five years and has three interrelated
            components: a) Research and monitoring (including monitoring
            of primate populations, genetics and habitat parameters,
            floral and faunal surveys, hydrological system studies,
            human resource utilization and promoting community based
            conservation); b) research management component which will
            provide incremental support to enable KWS to develop an
            adaptive management system and includes the Community
            Conservation Reserve as a sub-component; and c) community
            conservation and development component which will enhance
            implementation of KWS' existing Community Wildlife
            Program in the area.
